descript.abstract: This EnviroAtlas dataset is a point feature class showing the locations of stream confluences. Stream confluences are important components of fluvial networks. Hydraulic forces meeting at stream confluences often produce changes in streambed morphology and sediment distribution, and these changes often increase habitat heterogeneity relative to upstream and downstream locations. Increases in habitat heterogeneity at stream confluences have led some to identify them as biological hotspots. Despite their potential ecological importance, there are relatively few empirical studies documenting ecological patterns across the upstream-confluence-downstream gradient. To facilitate more studies of the ecological value and role of stream confluences in fluvial networks, we have produced a database of stream confluences and their associated watershed attributes for the conterminous United States. The database includes 1,085,629 stream confluences and 383 attributes for each confluence that are organized into 15 database tables for both tributary and mainstem upstream catchments ("local" watersheds) and watersheds. Themes represented by the database tables include hydrology (e.g., stream order), land cover and land cover change, geology (e.g., calcium content of underlying lithosphere), physical condition (e.g., precipitation), measures of ecological integrity, and stressors (e.g., impaired streams). We use measures of ecological integrity (Thornbrugh et al. 2018) from the StreamCat database (Hill et al. 2016) to classify stream confluences using disjoint clustering and validate the cluster results using decision tree analysis. This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose: The purpose of this dataset is to provide EPA stakeholders an extensive database on environmental condition of stream confluences. Stream confluences are often biological hotspots and Clean Water Act (CWA) 305(b)/303(d) assessments are commonly based on stream biota. The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.

procstep.procdesc: Copied the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) Plus v2.1 datasets for the lower 48 United States from the internal EnviroAtlas data repository. For original NHD Plus v2.1 documentation and metadata, see: www.horizon-systems.com/nhdplus/NHDPlusV2_documentation.php

Projected all NHDPlus version2 NHDFlowlines, NHDAreas, and NHDWaterbodies to the USGS Albers standard projection used for the National Land Cover Database (NLCD) dataset. The XY Resolution and Tolerance parameter within the Geoprocessing Environment Settings was set to 0.000001 Meters for the reprojection.

For each of the 18 2-digit NHD Hydrologic Unit (HUC) regions in the lower 48: 1)Selected the NHDFlowlines, NHDAreas, and NHDWaterbodies of interest (NHD flowlines were excluded if they did not have a catchment value attached to them; all coast flowlines and flowlines that occurred in lakes and ponds were also excluded. Flowlines that occurred in swamp areas were retained. Points where the remaining flowlines touched the coast were included in the dataset.); 2)Generated End Point vertices for the NHDFlowlines; 3) Selected the end points that either delimited an intersection between two or more flowlines, an intersection with a retained NHDWaterbody or NHDArea, or that intersected with a coastline. This is the NHD##_Confluence, where ## is the 2-digit NHD HUC region; 4) Deleted points from NHD##_Confluence layer that had the same XY coordinates. This is NHD##_Confluence_Pt; 5)Assigned the NHD##_Confluence_Pt ID to the NHD##_Confluence features that spatially overlapped; 6) Attributed the NHD##_Confluence_Pt layer with SRCount, SRTotArbol, and SRTotDASqk; 7) Assigned a BranchNum to each point in NHD##_Confluence; 8) Assigned CONFPT_ID values to NHD##_Confluence and NHD##_Confluence_Pt layers.

Merged all 18 2-digit NHD HUC versions of NHD##_Confluence into NHD_CONUS_Confluence_v2; Merged all 18 2-digit NHD HUC versions of NHD##_Confluence_Pt into NHD_CONUS_Confluence_Pt_v2; Generated table, NHD_CONUS_COMID_v2, using a Pivot Table operation
Associate attributes with points using data available through NHDplus V2 and StreamCat (https://www.epa.gov/national-aquatic-resource-surveys/streamcat)
Organize attributes by theme into theme-specific tables

Twelve Digit Hydrologic Unit Code. This field provides a unique 12-digit code for each subwatershed. Numbers were assigned in an upstream to downstream fashion. Where no downstream/upstream relationship could be determined, numbers were assigned in a clockwise fashion. -9999 indicates that the confluence did not fall inside of a 12-digit HUC, usually because the confluence point was located in the ocean, in the Great Lakes, or outside of US boundaries.

overview.eaover:
Database contains landscape attributes at catchment and watershed scales for stream confluences defined from 2 or more inflowing streams. Landscape attributes are divided into 15 tables covering land cover and change, stressors, hydrology, physical condition, and ecological integrity.
Additional details about this dataset are described in Ebert, D., Wickham, J., Neale, A., Mehaffey, M. 2020. A landscape assessment and associated dataset of stream confluences for the conterminous United States. Journal of the American Water Resources Association (JAWRA) 1 --13, https://doi.org/10.1111/1752-1688.12899.
